fields.headline: Thrills and chills
fields.bodyText: · Stay in a hotel constructed out of ice and snow at the Ice Hotel in Jukkasjarvi, a village in northern Swedish Lapland. This winter wonderland includes an ice-art exhibition, a cinema with ice screen, an ice chapel which can be used for weddings and christenings and the Absolut Ice bar, where drinks are served in glasses cut from river ice. Overnight guests can stay in stylish ice rooms, tucked up in thermal sleeping bags on beds of ice covered with reindeer skins to keep warm in temperatures that vary between -4C and - 9C (16-25F). Modern cabins are available, as are 'Aurora houses', which have skylights so you can watch the Northern Lights. When to go: The hotel is rebuilt every November, and opens on 13 December. Go before it all melts at the end of April. For summer attractions see www.icehotel.com. How to go: Scantours (020 7839 2927) has three-night packages for £875 per person. This includes return flights from Heathrow or Manchester to Stockholm, one night at the Hotel Esplanade, Stockholm and two nights at the Ice Hotel, with breakfasts, two lunches and one dinner. · If you fancy going further afield, visit the Ice Hotel in Quebec, Canada. The hotel is being built from 11,000 tons of ice and 350 tons of snow. Ice Hotel Quebec has two art galleries, a cinema, chapel, an Absolut bar and even a skating rink. Guests can enjoy a spa and join the polar bear club for a snow bath! With ceilings more than 16ft high and walls covered with original artwork this Ice Hotel has a unique Quebecois flavour. When to go: Opens 1 January to 31 March. How to go: Tailor Made Travel (01386 712050) offers a four-night trip from £773 per person. This includes return flights; two nights' half-board accommodation at the Ice Hotel and two nights room-only at the Auberge St Pierre hotel, Quebec City. · Carnival in the snow? Join the Winterlude festival in Ottawa, Canada, a celebration of all things frozen. The event attracts more than 700,000 visitors each year and boasts the longest ice skating rink in the world, the Rideau Canal. The Jacques Cartier Park is transformed into a family playground with snow slides, mazes and sculptures. Events include ice carving contests, ice-skating displays, concerts and dog-sled races. When to go: Winterlude is held over the first three weekends in February. How to go: Tailor Made Travel (01386 712050) has four nights room-only at the four-star Fairmont Chateau Laurier hotel, including return flights from Heathrow to Ottawa from £517pp, excluding festival tickets. Daily departures in February. · Take an unusual winter break to Kiruna in Swedish Lapland for the Snow Festival 2002, the biggest in Europe. It begins with a speech by the Mayor of Kiruna and King Winter arriving on a horse-drawn sleigh. Events include an ice sculpture competition, concerts, a reindeer race and even a fashion show. You can even enjoy Sami cultural activities, including jojk (traditional singing) crafts and reindeer sleigh rides. When to go: The Snow Festival runs from 29 January to 3 February 2002. How to go: Arctic Experience (01737 214214) has a seven-night B&B break to the festival from £694 per adult and £297 per child, including return flights between London and Kiruna, and the services of a local representative. Departs 27 January.
